attributes.title: Development of an Evidence and Gap Map of Interventions to increase Smoking Cessation: A Study Protocol
attributes.description:
Introduction:
Smoking remains one of the leading risk factors contributing to the global burden of disease. Sub-optimal implementation of evidence-based tobacco control and smoking cessation practice is a major challenge despite a substantial evidence base for interventions to increase smoking cessation globally. We aim to develop an Evidence Gap Map (EGM) to collate the existing evidence and identify the gaps in research on interventions to increase smoking cessation worldwide. An EGM creates a visual framework to collate the current evidence on interventions and their outcomes
Method:
A conceptual framework was developed followed by the formulation of a search strategy with, key search terms and search period (1970-till date). The search will be conducted in relevant bibliographic, systematic review and impact evaluation databases (including MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane Library, SCOPUS,3ie Impact Evaluation repository),with support from a research librarian. Subsequently, two coders will screen and retrieve systematic reviews and individual impact evaluation studies. The adapted SURE (Supporting the Use of Research Evidence) checklist will be used to evaluate the quality of the included systematic reviews and impact evaluations. A narrative synthesis from the systematic review findings and line listing of the impact evaluations will form the basis of this EGM. The EGM report will be presented in an interactive visual format. 
Ethics and dissemination: 
As this research involves published articles, it is exempted from ethical approval.  We will disseminate the research findings including the interactive map at relevant conferences and via peer-reviewed publications. 
Conclusion: 
The proposed EGM will organise the pieces of evidence generated in systematic reviews and impact evaluations on smoking cessation interventions and identify the current research gaps, if any. The findings will inform evidence-based practice and future research.

question.value:
We have drafted the comprehensive search strategy for this EGM. We have identified the key search terms that are focused on interventions to increase smoking cessation with their different approaches and outcomes. We have combined the key search terms for Ovid MEDLINE® (supplementary file). The searching keywords will be used for other bibliographic databases adapting the database-specific filters for study design. We will check the comprehensiveness of the search strategy through validating a few standard systematic reviews and impact evaluation articles prior to finalising the search terms. The research librarian will do this iterative process of testing the search strategy.  
We will implement the comprehensive search strategy to systematically search the relevant electronic bibliographic databases, systematic reviews databases, impact evaluation database and relevant bilateral agencies (e.g. WHO, CDC, World Bank). The bibliographic databases include: MEDLINE through PubMed, Web of Science, Embase, CINAHL, Scopus,   We will cover the following systematic review databases: the Cochrane Tobacco Addiction Group Trials Register, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Joanna Briggs systematic reviews, Evidence for Policy and Practice Information and Co-ordinating Centre (EPPI) systematic reviews database, Campbell Collaboration database and 3ie database of systematic reviews.
Impact evaluation databases will include the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), 3ie Impact Evaluation repository and Cochrane tobacco addiction group specialized register and the trial registry databases will include ClinicalTrials.gov and ICTRP (International Clinical Trials Registry Platform). We will search citations from the articles published in the websites of the bilateral national and international agencies who cover the smoking cessation or tobacco control. These will include: World Health Organization (WHO), WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) of United States of America (USA) and World Bank. 
Selection criteria:
We will include both systematic reviews and impact evaluation studies for evaluating smoking cessation intervention within the Intervention/ Outcome framework in our EGM to map the evidence and identify the gaps. Additionally, the impact evaluation studies, assessed the effectiveness and outcomes of tobacco control and smoking cessation interventions, will be included.
General inclusion criteria: 
•	Any systematic reviews or reviews of systematic reviews, evaluating the effectiveness or outcomes of the interventions for tobacco control and smoking cessation
•	Randomised Controlled Trial (RCT), Quasi-experimental studies or pre-and post-trial that evaluated the effectiveness and or outcomes of tobacco control and smoking cessation interventions 
•	Published between 1970- date of search
General Exclusion criteria: 
•	Any trials or review that does not measure the impact of a tobacco control or smoking cessation intervention
•	Any trials or reviews outlining the effect of smoking rather than the impact of tobacco control or smoking cessation interventions
•	Any ongoing trial and review which are not completed or not published yet
•	Non-systematic literature reviews
•	Letters to the editor, editorial comments etc.

Article selection process:
We will employ the standard methods of two-stage screening while selecting the articles for inclusion. Initially, we will screen search results for relevance based on the title and abstract. Two reviewers will check the eligibility of each article independently. A third reviewer will review any documents or articles for which there is disagreement. The final list of included articles will be determined by screening the full text. Screening for full text will be conducted by two independent reviewers as well. In all stages, any disagreement between the reviewers will be discussed with a third senior reviewer until resolved. We will use pre-defined inclusion and exclusion criteria (described in this protocol; Selection Criteria section) in both stages of screening. A sequence of exclusion criteria will be applied to reduce the chance of subjectivity in prioritising exclusion criteria. We will report the exclusion of an article with proper documentation. Where there are multiple publications from a single study, all will be reported. We will use the ROSES flow diagram to present the summary of the process, including the numbers of excluded and included articles

q14.value: This is systematic reviews of systematic reviews and impact evaluation studies hence sample size calculation is not applicable here.

question.value:
Population: People who smoke

Intervention:
A. Behavioural Interventions
-Brief intervention
-Quit lines
-mTobacco cessation (e.g. text messaging, phone call)
-Intensive behavioural support
-Smoking cessation clinics
B. Pharmacological intervention
-Nicotine replacement therapies (NRTs)
-Non-nicotine pharmacotherapies (e.g., bupropion, varenicline
C. Health care financing for promoting cessation activities (e.g. Subsidised therapies, incentives, insurance, training and educatation to healthcare personnel)  
D. Alternative therapies (e.g. acupuncture, yoga, exercise)
E. Campaign promoting smoking cessation supports

Comparison:
-Placebo
-No intervention 
-Usual care
-Minimal intervention
-Pre-post comparison of impact or outcomes

Outcome:
Primary outcomes
-Abstinence from smoking; self-reported or biochemically validated
    -Consumption of cigarette; self-reported
-Intention to Quit; the number of people setting a Quit date
-Prevalence of smoking
Secondary outcomes:
	-Increased use of smoking cessation support as an immediate impact
	-Smoking-related diseases
	-Smoking-related hospital admissions
	-Cost-effectiveness (e.g. costs, savings, incremental cost)
	-Acceptability, i.e. proportion of smokers continue to receive the treatment for the recommended duration
We will not use any statistical model to analyse the data in this EGM study.

We will produce a narrative synthesis by describing the interventions and outcomes of the systematic reviews and impact evaluations. We will generate a geographical information system (GIS) map showing the frequency distribution of the impact evaluation studies conducted in different countries in the world. We will tabulate the studies on different tobacco control and smoking cessation interventions. We will list the different outcomes of the tabulated interventions. We will present the frequencies of studies conducted for separate tobacco control and smoking cessation interventions along with their outcomes in a graph. Alongside, we will describe the key characteristics of the population for a particular intervention.
All efforts for the data analysis in the EGM will allow us to explore the existing evidence of smoking cessation interventions. It will provide us with the opportunity to identify the ‘absolute evidence gaps’ (i.e. no studies for a particular intervention) and ‘synthesis gaps’ (several impact evaluation literature, but no high confidence systematic reviews). This gap will initiate a new systematic review or evidence synthesis study afterwards.

q22.value:
Inclusion criteria: 
•	Any systematic reviews or reviews of systematic reviews, evaluating the effectiveness or outcomes of the interventions for tobacco control and smoking cessation
•	Randomised Controlled Trial (RCT), Quasi-experimental studies or pre-and post-trial that evaluated the effectiveness and or outcomes of tobacco control and smoking cessation interventions 
•	Published between 1970- date of search
Exclusion criteria: 
•	Any trials or review that does not measure the impact of a tobacco control or smoking cessation intervention
•	Any trials or reviews outlining the effect of smoking rather than the impact of tobacco control or smoking cessation interventions
•	Any ongoing trial and review which are not completed or not published yet
•	Non-systematic literature reviews
•	Letters to the editor, editorial comments etc.

q25.value:
We will present the findings after the analysis of the extracted data in a visual-interactive format using 3ie’s customised platform. We will attach a detailed report of the EGM with this platform.  A computer programmer will help us to create this visual and dynamic platform by transforming the intervention-outcome framework into a matrix followed by the uploading of CSV files with data for all systematic reviews and impact evaluation studies included in the map (intervention, outcome, study design for impact evaluation, systematic review confidence grade, geographical location etc.). The colour grade of the map will indicate the evidence grade and the size of the plotting will indicate the number of studies to the audience.
EGMs synthesise the information that is available on what interventions are effective by specific themes. The method allows us to collect thematic evidence from systematic reviews and impact evaluations on the interventions and outcomes of the defined theme. EGM creates a visual presentation of the quantity and quality of systematic reviews and lists the impact evaluations. It creates demand for generating and synthesising new evidence. It helps policymakers to see and choose an intervention for a specific area from the collated evidence.
Our EGM will employ a best practice model by preparing frameworks of intervention/outcome and PICO terms from the stakeholder consultation and by incorporating a systematic search strategy, specific inclusion and exclusion criteria, and systematically report all available studies. Our protocol is the first step to ensure compliance with best practice. This EGM will allow us to collate evidence and recognise any gap in current interventions for smoking cessation. 
The limitation of this research is, it will not synthesise any new evidence by doing a meta-analysis. It will not focus on the strength of the effectiveness of a specific intervention. However, it might identify one or more interventions to choose for new systematic reviews and meta-analysis. As the articles of impact evaluations are systematically searched and retrieved in the EGM, the next steps for new systematic reviews will be economical in terms of efforts, time and budget.

attributes.title: moral inconsistency in selection of decision-rules

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Moral inconsistency in children's selection of decision-rules - not merely "inconsistency" alone.

other.value: We have a final question about which of the two characters (circle or square) children would rather play with. We do not have strong predictions about this DV and it is merely exploratory, although we suspect that if there is a difference between conditions, children would more likely select to play with the distributor (square) in the condition.

sample.value: We will be collecting 90 participants per cell—30 per two-year age bracket. As there are 2 between-subjects conditions, we will be collecting 180 participants altogether.

analyses.value:
We will use a linear regression with fairness evaluation at T2 as the dependent variable. Condition (Advantage Self or Advantage Other) and age (continuous) will be set as independent variables. 

As stated above, because all participants see an identical stimuli for T1 between conditions we will not analyze these data and instead will compare evaluations starting at T2. Based on the notion that children respond negatively to moral inconsistency that benefits the self (as compared to inconsistency more generally), we predict that there will be a main effect of Condition in that fairness evaluations will be generally higher in the Advantage Other condition than in the Advantage Self condition. We additionally predict that there will be no effect of age.

outliers.value: We will collect two different attention checks across the study the study in which the child is asked to recall who did a good or bad job cleaning in the classroom after each timepoint. If a child fails two attention checks then they will be excluded.

dependent.value:
Children will be asked to give fairness evaluations after each distribution is seen. Responses will be coded on a four-point likert scale with ‘very fair’ coded as four and ‘very unfair’ coded as one. 

Children will be asked for these fairness evaluations after each day & distribution seen, resulting in two time-points in total (e.g., T1 and T2 fairness evaluations).

conditions.value: There will be two conditions (Advantage Self and Advantage Other) to which participants will be assigned randomly. We will also analyze age as a continuous IV.

hypothesis.value:
In a previous study, we examined whether or not children attend to moral inconsistency in decision rules used. Prior work in the literature has demonstrated that children increasingly are sensitive to understanding the impartiality of some procedures as they age (Grocke, Rossano, & Tomasello, 2015; Shaw and Olson, 2014). However, not all impartial procedures are always impartial, and they can often be used to justify policy that benefits the self (Descioli, Massenkoff, Shaw, Petersen, & Kurzban, 2014). The current study examines children’s sensitivity to when others use impartial procedures selectively to selfishly advantage the self. In a previous experiment, we show children a story of a distributor that uses two different decision-rules that research demonstrates children generally consider to be fair: equal distribution (LoBue, Nishida, Chiong, DeLoache, J. & Haidt, 2011) and merit-based distribution (Baumard, Mascaro, & Chevallier, 2012). In two conditions, the distributor either distributes selfishly (changing the decision-rule used when it advantages himself) or consistently (keeping the decision-rule constant even if it disadvantages himself). We measure children’s fairness evaluations across two time points in the story to examine how fairness evaluations change after the distributor is shown to selectively choose impartial procedures. We find that children generally think both equal distribution and merit-based distribution are fair. However, children rate an inconsistent decision-rule change significantly less fair than a consistent decision-rule change. 

However, this study does not control for whether or not children merely like inconsistency in decision-rule itself instead of moral inconsistency specifically. Thus, in this next study, we examine whether or not children merely dislike inconsistency by telling participants a story very similar to our previous study. Instead, however, the distributor changes his decision rule across two different time points in both conditions. In this study, whether or not the distributor changes the decision-rule used (here, from merit to equality) remains constant across conditions. We vary between condition whether or not the distributor changes the decision rule used on Day 2 to selfishly advantage the self (Advantage Self condition) or instead advantage the other (Advantage Other condition). 

Specifically, children are told a story about two characters in a classroom: Circle and Square. These characters have to help clean the classroom and distribute some resources across two days (two different time points). Across both days, children are told that Square is always the character who is deciding how the resources are distributed. 

In both conditions, children see an identical Day 1: There are four markers in the classroom and Circle and Square have to help clean today. They see that Square does a good job helping to clean the classroom whereas Circle does a not so good job. They are then told that Square is going to decide how to share the resources. Square decides to use a merit rule on Day 1 (e.g., the person who did a better job gets more stickers) and children see a distribution in which Square takes three for himself (who did a better job) and gives one to Circle (who did a not so good job). After this first distribution, children are asked to evaluate how fair that was. We expect that, as there is no difference in what children see between conditions by this point, that children’s fairness evaluations should be equivalent across conditions as they see the same stimuli. We include this fairness evaluation only to keep identical the structure of the previous study, as well as to help children stay engaged throughout the course of the story.  

What we expect to differ across conditions is how fair children evaluate the distribution at Day 2. Children in both conditions are told that Square changes his mind on the second day and decides to use an equality rule to distribute the resources: i.e., he decides to split the markers evenly between himself and Circle no matter how well they each did at helping to clean. The only difference between the conditions is who did a better job: in the Advantage Self condition, Square does a worse job than Circle at helping to clean the classroom. In the Advantage Other condition, Square does a better job than Circle at helping to clean the classroom. Although Square is inconsistent with which decision-rule he uses in both conditions, we predict that children will evaluate the distribution in the Advantage Self condition as far more unfair than the Advantage Other condition. Specifically, Square will be seen as more unfair when he switches to an equality rule that benefits himself (giving equally rather than less to himself as would be consistent witht he “merit rule”) than one in which he does not benefit himself (giving equally rather than giving more to himself that would be consistent with the “merit rule). 

Thus, this study rules demonstrates that it is not inconsistency per se that children find objectionable, but instead inconsistency that is used to benefit the self.

Children will be asked to give fairness evaluations after each distribution is seen. Responses will be coded on a four-point likert scale with ‘very fair’ coded as four and ‘very unfair’ coded as one. 

Children will be asked for these fairness evaluations after each day & distribution seen, resulting in two time-points in total (e.g., T1 and T2 fairness evaluations).
registration_responses.conditions: There will be two conditions (Advantage Self and Advantage Other) to which participants will be assigned randomly. We will also analyze age as a continuous IV.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
In a previous study, we examined whether or not children attend to moral inconsistency in decision rules used. Prior work in the literature has demonstrated that children increasingly are sensitive to understanding the impartiality of some procedures as they age (Grocke, Rossano, & Tomasello, 2015; Shaw and Olson, 2014). However, not all impartial procedures are always impartial, and they can often be used to justify policy that benefits the self (Descioli, Massenkoff, Shaw, Petersen, & Kurzban, 2014). The current study examines children’s sensitivity to when others use impartial procedures selectively to selfishly advantage the self. In a previous experiment, we show children a story of a distributor that uses two different decision-rules that research demonstrates children generally consider to be fair: equal distribution (LoBue, Nishida, Chiong, DeLoache, J. & Haidt, 2011) and merit-based distribution (Baumard, Mascaro, & Chevallier, 2012). In two conditions, the distributor either distributes selfishly (changing the decision-rule used when it advantages himself) or consistently (keeping the decision-rule constant even if it disadvantages himself). We measure children’s fairness evaluations across two time points in the story to examine how fairness evaluations change after the distributor is shown to selectively choose impartial procedures. We find that children generally think both equal distribution and merit-based distribution are fair. However, children rate an inconsistent decision-rule change significantly less fair than a consistent decision-rule change. 

However, this study does not control for whether or not children merely like inconsistency in decision-rule itself instead of moral inconsistency specifically. Thus, in this next study, we examine whether or not children merely dislike inconsistency by telling participants a story very similar to our previous study. Instead, however, the distributor changes his decision rule across two different time points in both conditions. In this study, whether or not the distributor changes the decision-rule used (here, from merit to equality) remains constant across conditions. We vary between condition whether or not the distributor changes the decision rule used on Day 2 to selfishly advantage the self (Advantage Self condition) or instead advantage the other (Advantage Other condition). 

Specifically, children are told a story about two characters in a classroom: Circle and Square. These characters have to help clean the classroom and distribute some resources across two days (two different time points). Across both days, children are told that Square is always the character who is deciding how the resources are distributed. 

In both conditions, children see an identical Day 1: There are four markers in the classroom and Circle and Square have to help clean today. They see that Square does a good job helping to clean the classroom whereas Circle does a not so good job. They are then told that Square is going to decide how to share the resources. Square decides to use a merit rule on Day 1 (e.g., the person who did a better job gets more stickers) and children see a distribution in which Square takes three for himself (who did a better job) and gives one to Circle (who did a not so good job). After this first distribution, children are asked to evaluate how fair that was. We expect that, as there is no difference in what children see between conditions by this point, that children’s fairness evaluations should be equivalent across conditions as they see the same stimuli. We include this fairness evaluation only to keep identical the structure of the previous study, as well as to help children stay engaged throughout the course of the story.  

What we expect to differ across conditions is how fair children evaluate the distribution at Day 2. Children in both conditions are told that Square changes his mind on the second day and decides to use an equality rule to distribute the resources: i.e., he decides to split the markers evenly between himself and Circle no matter how well they each did at helping to clean. The only difference between the conditions is who did a better job: in the Advantage Self condition, Square does a worse job than Circle at helping to clean the classroom. In the Advantage Other condition, Square does a better job than Circle at helping to clean the classroom. Although Square is inconsistent with which decision-rule he uses in both conditions, we predict that children will evaluate the distribution in the Advantage Self condition as far more unfair than the Advantage Other condition. Specifically, Square will be seen as more unfair when he switches to an equality rule that benefits himself (giving equally rather than less to himself as would be consistent witht he “merit rule”) than one in which he does not benefit himself (giving equally rather than giving more to himself that would be consistent with the “merit rule). 

Thus, this study rules demonstrates that it is not inconsistency per se that children find objectionable, but instead inconsistency that is used to benefit the self.

attributes.title: Democracy Dies in Darkness: Dark Triad and Political Attitudes

q1.value: Democracy Dies in Darkness: The Dark Side of Political Mindsets

q3.value: The purpose of the current study is to examine the relations between Dark Tetrad traits (narcissism, Machiavellianism, psychopathy, and sadism) and political mindsets (right-wing authoritarianism, fascism, ethnonationalism, and social dominance orientation). Past research has reported mixed findings on the relationship between dark personality traits and political mindsets that inform behavior and political orientation. The relation between personality and political mindsets is relevant to understanding individual differences in the adoption of political beliefs associated with dangerous or negative behavioral outcomes. The current study will also explore political orientation as a moderator of the relation between Dark Tetrad traits and political mindsets.

q4.value:
1) There will be a positive correlation between the Dark Tetrad traits and RWA. 
2) There will be a positive correlation between the Dark Tetrad traits and SDO-Dominance.
3) There will be a positive correlation between the Dark Tetrad traits and SDO-Egalitarianism.
4) There will be a positive correlation between the Dark Tetrad traits and fascism.
5) There will be a positive correlation between the Dark Tetrad traits and ethnonationalism.
6) There will be a positive correlation between the Dark Tetrad traits and political conservatism.
7) There will be a negative correlation between the Dark Tetrad traits and political liberalism.
8) Political conservatism will moderate the relation between the Dark Tetrad and RWA.
9) Political conservatism will moderate the relation between the Dark Tetrad and Ethnonationalism.
10) Political conservatism will moderate the relation between the Dark Tetrad and fascism.
11) Political conservatism will moderate the relation between the Dark Tetrad and both forms of social dominance orientation.
12) Informant ratings of the primary participants’ Dark Tetrad traits will be associated with the informants’ perception that the primary participant has extreme political views.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The current study is a cross-sectional observational study that will use self-report and informant-report measures of personality and political mindsets.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The primary participants will be University of Oregon students recruited from the Human Subjects Pool using the SONA website. All primary participants will receive 1.0 credits for their hour of participation. All primary participants will be 18 years of age or older. Primary participants (those completing self-report questionnaires) will participate online and will participate only once (i.e., the survey includes only one session of data collection and is expected to be completed in one sitting). They will also be asked for the first names and email addresses for three people (informants) they believe know them well and who are 18 years of age or older. Informants will not be rewarded for their participation and this will be clearly communicated in the email asking them to complete the informant survey. All informants will be 18 years of age or older. Responses to the surveys completed by the primary participants and the three informants will be recorded through Qualtrics. Participants with a response standard deviation under 0.5 and/or a completion time under 10 minutes will be excluded. For any analyses involving gender as a variable, participants who do not identify as either male or female will be excluded.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 400 primary participants. At most, data on 500 primary participants and 1500 informants will be collected. Overall, data will only be collected from a maximum of 2000 people (500 primary participants and 1500 informants).

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a moderate to large correlation at a Holm-Bonferroni-corrected alpha level of .0002.

q15.value: We will continue recruiting participants from the University of Oregon Human Subjects Pool until we have 400 primary participants, or until the end of the summer 2020 term, whichever comes later (i.e. if we do not have 400 primary participants by the end of the summer 2020 term, we will continue data collection until we reach our target sample size, but if we reach 400 primary participants before that cutoff point, we will continue data collection until the end of the summer 2020 term).

question.value: Participants will complete the following measures: (1) the Mach IV measure of Machiavellianism, (2) the NPI-13/NPI-16 measures of narcissism, (3) the LSRP measure of psychopathy, (4) the CAST measure of sadistic tendencies, (5) the Right-Wing Authoritarianism Scale (Altemeyer, 1998), (6) the Social Dominance Orientation Scale (which has two dimensions: Dominance and Egalitarianism) (Ho et al., 2012), (7) the Ethnonationalism scale (Saucier, 2013), (8) the Fascism Scale (Saucier, 2013), (9) the Political Belief Scale (Webber et al., 2018), (10) two political orientation questions, and (11) demographic data (i.e., age, gender identity, and cultural/ethnic identity). The three informants will be emailed a short survey asking them to rate the primary participant on the SD4 measure of Machiavellianism, narcissism, psychopathy, and sadism. They will also be asked whether they believe the primary participant holds extreme political views. Other measures will be collected as part of the present study, but they are not discussed here as they are not relevant to the above hypotheses.

We will average the items for each respective scale into a total score for the primary participants. Specifically, we will calculate a total score for the Mach-IV, the NPI-13, the LSRP, the CAST, the RWA scale, the ethnonationalism scale, and the fascism scale. For the SDO, we will calculate a score for the egalitarianism and dominance facets. For the Political Belief Scale, we will calculate a score for the liberalism, conservatism, and moderatism facets. 

For the informant ratings, we will first average the items for each respective subscale of the SD4. We will then average each of the informants’ scores for each of the subscales to create an average informant rating of each primary participants’ level of Machiavellianism, narcissism, psychopathy, and sadism. The informants’ ratings of whether the participant has extreme political beliefs or not will be averaged to produce a single value. 

Facet scores of the LSRP, Mach-IV (Monoghan’s two-dimension solution), NPI-13, and the CAST will also be calculated, but these will not be used to test the hypothesis. They will be examined in concert with the political mindsets in an exploratory fashion.

We will calculate zero-order correlations between all variables. These will be used to test hypotheses 1-7. 

We will also construct a separate model predicting each of the political mindsets (i.e., RWA, ethnonationalism, fascism, SDO-egalitarianism, and SDO-dominance) from the participants’ levels of Machiavellianism, narcissism, psychopathy, and sadism. We will also include the participants’ genders in the models to account for previously documented gender-related differences in the Dark Triad traits (Muris, Merckelbach, Otgaar, & Meijer, 2017). To test hypotheses 8-11, we will add an interaction term between political conservatism and the Dark Tetrad traits in a second model.

q20.value: There are no planned transformations to the data.

q21.value: For the zero-order correlations and multiple regression predictors, a p-value of 0.05 (two-tailed) will be used. The p-values for the zero-order correlations will be adjusted using the Holm-Bonferroni method prior to interpretation. The strength of the correlations will be interpreted using the benchmarks from Gignac and Szodorai (2016) for individual differences research: 0.10 as a weak correlation, 0.20 as a moderate correlation, and 0.30 as a strong correlation.

q22.value: Participants with a response standard deviation under 0.5 and/or a completion time under 10 minutes will be excluded. For any analyses involving gender as a variable, participants who do not identify as either a woman or a man will be excluded. We will consider a data point with a Cook’s d of over three times the mean Cook’s d to be a possible outlier. We will consider the potential outliers in the context of other values in order to confirm whether we believe it is an outlier. If an outlier is confirmed, the analyses will be run both with and without the outlier and, if the outlier does not meaningfully change the results of the analyses, it will be retained.

q23.value: Incomplete responses will be discarded. This does not include cases where the participant completed the entire survey and failed to provide informant information or cases where the participant failed to click through to the debriefing form.

q24.value:
Additional analyses may be conducted investigating the relations among the subscales of the Dark Tetrad traits (i.e., Machiavellian tactics, a Machiavellianism worldview, psychopathic egocentricity, psychopathic callousness, psychopathic antisociality, narcissistic leadership/authority, narcissistic grandiose exhibitionism, narcissistic entitlement/exploitativeness, vicarious sadism, physical sadism, verbal sadism) and the political mindsets. If included in the final manuscript, all of these analyses will be explicitly described as exploratory. 

Additional analyses may also be conducted investigating the relations among self-report ratings of the Dark Tetrad traits, informant-report ratings of the Dark Tetrad traits, and the self-report ratings of the political mindsets. Again, these analyses will be explicitly described as exploratory.

attributes.title: Improving the sexual health of young people in high risk populations: a systematic review of behavioural and psychosocial interventions.

q1.value: Improving the sexual health of young people in high risk populations: a systematic review of behavioural and psychosocial interventions.

q2.value: Samantha Lo Monaco, Ellie Brown, Richard Gray, Elizabeth Hughes, Brian O'Donoghue

q3.value:
Good sexual health is characterised not only by the absence of sexually-acquired infections or unplanned pregnancy, but also by the presence of pleasure, positivity, and respect. It should also be free from exploitation and violence. Adolescence is a time when many biological, psychological, and social changes occur, as well as being the time when many become sexually active. Thus, sexual health is of critical concern in this time period (≥25).

Certain at-risk groups are more likely to experience adverse sexual health outcomes, and this review will identify and evaluate the behavioural interventions designed to target these groups.

q4.value: As we are reviewing previously published and ongoing trials, we have no hypotheses to report.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic review of previously published and ongoing studies, following PRISMA guidelines.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: We have not begun extraction of existing data.

question.value:
Searches were conducted using online databases to identify relevant studies. Beginning on August 24, 2019, the databases searched were MEDLINE, PsycINFO, Excerpta Medica Database (EMBASE), Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), Web of Science, and Scopus. Ongoing and unpublished trials were searched for at ClinicalTrials.gov, Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR), and the World Health Organization’s ISRCTN registry. 

We have used Covidence review software to screen all studies for inclusion.

Please see the attached files for an example of our search strategy, and inclusion and exclusion criteria.

q13.value: 1187 papers were identified through searches. Of those, 1028 were excluded during title and abstract screening, and 113 were excluded during full text screening. 47 studies will be included in the review.

question.value: Scores on standardised outcome measures of sexual health, as used by each trial. This includes changes in behaviour, e.g., incidence of condom usage, sexually-transmitted infections, and unwanted pregnancy. These outcome measures will vary by trial.

In this case, statistical testing has already been conducted by the respective authors of each completed trial. We will use Cochrane's Risk of Bias tool to evaluate the quality of all studies, and evaluate their effectiveness using the reported results.

attributes.title: Analysis Of The Effect Of Organizational Culture On Performance Of Employees (Case Study Of The Kominfo Office Of Pariaman City)
attributes.description: This study aims to analyze, Influence Organizational Culture Against Employee Performance At the Office of Communications and Information Technology of Pariaman. This research is a quantitative research that shows a causal relationship. The sample in this study were 47 employees. Data collection techniques used were observation, questionnaire and documentation. Data analysis techniques used are descriptive statistical analysis using percentages, averages, and standard deviations and for inferential statistical analysis using data normality tests, simple linear regression analysis, and product moment correlation analysis. The results of the study show that the organizational culture is in a very good category in terms of indicators, namely: Innovation and Courage to take risks; Attention to detail; Results oriented; Human oriented; Team oriented; Aggressive; and stable. Employee performance is in a very good category in terms of indicators of discipline of service personnel, responsibility of service personnel, ability of service personnel, politeness and friendliness of officers, based on simple linear regression analysis shows that there is an influence of organizational culture on employee performance at the Pariaman City Communication and Information Agency Pariaman City. From the results of product moment correlation analysis obtained a significant level of relationship between the influence of organizational culture on the performance of employees at the Office of Communication and Information Office of Pariaman City, Pariaman City with the Strong category.

From the results of product moment correlation analysis obtained a significant level of relationship between the influence of organizational culture on the performance of employees at the Office of Communication and Information Office of Pariaman City, Pariaman City with the Strong category.

q1.value: The effect of delay length on time preferences across adulthood

q2.value: Shelby Denise Leverett, Kendra Leigh Seaman, Christopher Garza

q3.value: Many decisions involve considering trade-offs between a smaller sooner option and a larger later option. In these situations, people tend to devalue, or discount, the later option. This devaluation is known as temporal discounting. If the smaller, sooner option occurs now, this is known as delay discounting. If the smaller, sooner option occurs in the future, this is known as intertemporal discounting. The extent to which the later option is discounted varies largely between people, and research has shown mixed age effects. Some studies have found that with age, people discount more steeply, others have found that with age people discount less steeply, and others have not found any evidence that age has an effect on temporal discounting at all.  We posit that one of the reasons for these heterogeneous results is that existing studies have used a mixture of time delays, ranging from days to years. One prominent theory of aging, socioemotional selectivity theory (SST), suggests that older adults become more present-oriented than younger adults because their future is more limited. Because of limited time horizons, older adults view the future as more uncertain, and this uncertainty may lead older adults to discount future rewards more than younger adults. Thus, for older adults, the greater the delay between now and an outcome, the greater their uncertainty about whether they will be alive and able to realize that outcome. This predicts that for longer time delays, older adults will discount more than younger adults. However, for shorter time delays older adults should not show a differences from younger adults. This hypothesis has not been empirically tested. Our goal is to clarify the effect that age has on delay discounting by systematically examining discounting when time delays of vary greatly in terms of magnitude.

q4.value:
H1: We hypothesize that across all ages, we will see greater discounting (or greater proportion of sooner options) with longer time delays.

H2: We hypothesize that this increase in discounting for longer time delays will vary by age. Specifically, we predict that age differences in time preferences will only appear with longer time delays. For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

Independent variables: age (between-subjects), discount rate (within-subjects) and time interval (within-subjects)
Dependent variable: proportion of smaller, sooner options chosen
Potential moderators (exploratory analyses): Future Time Perspective, Safety Net and Savings 

Other exploratory analyses: Impact of time label (large number, small unit (e.g. 7 days) vs. small number large unit (e.g. 1 week)

q9.value: The order in which the time delays are presented in the delayed discounting trials is randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants: We will collect data from 276 participants (ages 25-84). The sample will be subdivided into six age categories, or bins (i.e: 25-34, 35-44, 45-54, 55-64. 65-74, 75-84). Each bin will have an equal number of participants (i.e: 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23). Finally, to build a sample that is representative of the US population, we will recruit participants to match the racial diversity described in the most recent US census (i.e: 75% Caucasian, 13% African-American, 5% Asian, etc).
Participants will be recruited with Qualtrics Panels, a service designed to recruit individuals from pre-existing participant pools, based on the criteria of researchers. Qualtrics Panels compensates the participant with Qualtrics points that can ultimately be redeemed for gift cards. We will include healthy participants between the ages of 25-84 and exclude participants with any psychological or neurological health issues as indicated by our online screening survey. 
      

Procedure: The entirety of the study takes places online through a Qualtrics survey. Participants will first answer a brief screening for our inclusion and exclusion criteria (age, gender, and psychological or neurological health issues). Eligible participants will then be consented. This is followed by the demographic questionnaire for age, ethnicity, income, and subjective health. Next, participants will complete the Future Time Perspective (FTP) survey, a 10-item scale to measure their subjective perception of how much time they feel they have left to live. This will be followed by the delay discounting practice round and task, in which participants choose which option they would prefer when presented with a smaller, sooner and a larger, later option.  Finally, they will be presented with the Savings and Safety Net subscale (from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau) to assess their saving habits and financial security across their lifetime . The total survey duration is estimated to be 7-8 minutes.

q13.value: As indicated by power analyses, we will have a sample size of 276 individuals between the ages of 25 and 85 years old. The sample will be subdivided into six age bins (i.e 25-34 35-44,...75-85) and within each age bin there will be an equal number of participants (i.e 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23).

q14.value: In order to detect a small effect size (Cohen's d= 0.2) with 80% power, power analyses indicated that we would need a sample size of 275. The sample was rounded to 276 to have an equal number of participants in each of the six bins.

q15.value: Qualtrics Panels will terminate participant recruitment and data collection when we have reached the target sample size, with the target composition of participants in each bin (i.e: equal numbers of men and women).

question.value:
We are manipulating the time delay between the smaller, sooner option and the larger, later option. There are 4 levels of this variable: days, weeks, months, years. Each level has 3 sub-levels: a low-point, a midpoint, and a high-point. To enable investigations into framing effects, the high-point of one level is equivalent to the low-point of the subsequent level (i.e: 12 months and 1 year).

The delay discounting task itself is comprised of 36 task trials, and 3 catch trials which are used as attention checks. We use a combination of 12 time intervals and 3 hypothetical discount rates to create 36 delay discounting trials. We use the following time intervals: 1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 4 weeks, 1 month, 6 months, 12 months, 1 year, 5 year, and 10 years. We use the three different discount rates: k= .1, k= .05, and k=.005. In order to estimate an appropriate future amount, corresponding to the three discount rates and the given time delays, we used the following formula: reward=SV * (1+ k*days). In this formula, SV (subjective value) is the dollar amount of the reward today (set to $10 in every trial), reward is the dollar amount in the future after a given time delay, k is the discount rate, and days is the time delay (given in days). We operationalized a month to be 28 days.

The primary outcome variable is the acceptance rate, or the proportion of sooner options chosen in the delay discounting task. We will measure age (in years) as the continuous covariate, and will measure future time perspective, as measured by the FTP scale (Carstensen and Lang, 1996), as a mediator.
- KS: should I add our demographic questions & savings & safety net questions here too?

H1: We hypothesize that across all ages, we will see greater discounting (or greater proportion of sooner options) with longer time delays.

H2: We hypothesize that this increase in discounting for longer time delays will vary by age. Specifically, we predict that age differences in time preferences will only appear with longer time delays. For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.

We will test these hypotheses by predicting the proportion of sooner options chosen with two models:

First, we will test a 3 (k-values: 0.1, 0.05, 0.005) by 4 (time: days, weeks, months, years) by Age (25-84 years) ANCOVA. 

H1: Main effect of delay with longer delays (years) having greater acceptance of sooner option.
H2: Age * Delay interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (years)

Next, we will convert the categorical predictors above into continuous variables. The three k values will be log-transformed (-1, -1.301, -2.301) to reduce skewness and the twelve time delays will be converted into a common scale: number of days (1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 14 days, 28 days, 30 days, 180 days, 365 days, 1825 days, 1650 days). These two continuous predictors (log(k) and delay in days) will be used in a linear model.


H1: Main effect of number of days such that longer delays ( > 365 days) having greater acceptance of the sooner option.
H2: Age * number of days interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (>365 days)

q21.value:
We will use two-tailed tests with a p-value of .05 to make inferences. 

When necessary, we will use Bonferroni corrections for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: We will include three catch trials in the delay discounting task where there is an obvious correct answer (unlike the other trials in the delay discounting task). If a participant chooses incorrectly on one of these catch trials, their survey immediately ends and they are escorted out of the session. We will not use the data from participants who are excluded due to catch trials, as we want to ensure that everyone is attending to the task, especially when it is so short. We plan to include all of the rest of the data points from other participants in our analyses.

q23.value: We don't expect to have any missing data. As the survey is being conducted online in Qualtrics, each question has been built to require a response before the participant can move on to the next question.

q24.value:
First, plan to investigate framing effects. We will test frame (large number with small unit vs small number with large unit) and Age on discounting in the relevant subset of trials. 

Second, we are curious about the relationship between future time perspective and discounting. We will test if FTP mediates the relationship between age and discounting, and whether or not this relationship is moderated by time delay.

Finally, we plan to investigate whether discount rates correlate with lifetime saving habits, specifically with the amount of money in liquid savings. If this relationship is found to be significant, we will control for wealth in our analyses.

registration_responses.q3: Many decisions involve considering trade-offs between a smaller sooner option and a larger later option. In these situations, people tend to devalue, or discount, the later option. This devaluation is known as temporal discounting. If the smaller, sooner option occurs now, this is known as delay discounting. If the smaller, sooner option occurs in the future, this is known as intertemporal discounting. The extent to which the later option is discounted varies largely between people, and research has shown mixed age effects. Some studies have found that with age, people discount more steeply, others have found that with age people discount less steeply, and others have not found any evidence that age has an effect on temporal discounting at all.  We posit that one of the reasons for these heterogeneous results is that existing studies have used a mixture of time delays, ranging from days to years. One prominent theory of aging, socioemotional selectivity theory (SST), suggests that older adults become more present-oriented than younger adults because their future is more limited. Because of limited time horizons, older adults view the future as more uncertain, and this uncertainty may lead older adults to discount future rewards more than younger adults. Thus, for older adults, the greater the delay between now and an outcome, the greater their uncertainty about whether they will be alive and able to realize that outcome. This predicts that for longer time delays, older adults will discount more than younger adults. However, for shorter time delays older adults should not show a differences from younger adults. This hypothesis has not been empirically tested. Our goal is to clarify the effect that age has on delay discounting by systematically examining discounting when time delays of vary greatly in terms of magnitude.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: We hypothesize that across all ages, we will see greater discounting (or greater proportion of sooner options) with longer time delays.

H2: We hypothesize that this increase in discounting for longer time delays will vary by age. Specifically, we predict that age differences in time preferences will only appear with longer time delays. For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: The order in which the time delays are presented in the delayed discounting trials is randomized.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: As indicated by power analyses, we will have a sample size of 276 individuals between the ages of 25 and 85 years old. The sample will be subdivided into six age bins (i.e 25-34 35-44,...75-85) and within each age bin there will be an equal number of participants (i.e 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23).
registration_responses.q14: In order to detect a small effect size (Cohen's d= 0.2) with 80% power, power analyses indicated that we would need a sample size of 275. The sample was rounded to 276 to have an equal number of participants in each of the six bins.
registration_responses.q15: Qualtrics Panels will terminate participant recruitment and data collection when we have reached the target sample size, with the target composition of participants in each bin (i.e: equal numbers of men and women).
registration_responses.q21:
We will use two-tailed tests with a p-value of .05 to make inferences. 

When necessary, we will use Bonferroni corrections for multiple comparisons.
registration_responses.q22: We will include three catch trials in the delay discounting task where there is an obvious correct answer (unlike the other trials in the delay discounting task). If a participant chooses incorrectly on one of these catch trials, their survey immediately ends and they are escorted out of the session. We will not use the data from participants who are excluded due to catch trials, as we want to ensure that everyone is attending to the task, especially when it is so short. We plan to include all of the rest of the data points from other participants in our analyses.
registration_responses.q23: We don't expect to have any missing data. As the survey is being conducted online in Qualtrics, each question has been built to require a response before the participant can move on to the next question.
registration_responses.q24:
First, plan to investigate framing effects. We will test frame (large number with small unit vs small number with large unit) and Age on discounting in the relevant subset of trials. 

Second, we are curious about the relationship between future time perspective and discounting. We will test if FTP mediates the relationship between age and discounting, and whether or not this relationship is moderated by time delay.

Finally, we plan to investigate whether discount rates correlate with lifetime saving habits, specifically with the amount of money in liquid savings. If this relationship is found to be significant, we will control for wealth in our analyses.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Independent variables: age (between-subjects), discount rate (within-subjects) and time interval (within-subjects)
Dependent variable: proportion of smaller, sooner options chosen
Potential moderators (exploratory analyses): Future Time Perspective, Safety Net and Savings 

Other exploratory analyses: Impact of time label (large number, small unit (e.g. 7 days) vs. small number large unit (e.g. 1 week)
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants: We will collect data from 276 participants (ages 25-84). The sample will be subdivided into six age categories, or bins (i.e: 25-34, 35-44, 45-54, 55-64. 65-74, 75-84). Each bin will have an equal number of participants (i.e: 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23). Finally, to build a sample that is representative of the US population, we will recruit participants to match the racial diversity described in the most recent US census (i.e: 75% Caucasian, 13% African-American, 5% Asian, etc).
Participants will be recruited with Qualtrics Panels, a service designed to recruit individuals from pre-existing participant pools, based on the criteria of researchers. Qualtrics Panels compensates the participant with Qualtrics points that can ultimately be redeemed for gift cards. We will include healthy participants between the ages of 25-84 and exclude participants with any psychological or neurological health issues as indicated by our online screening survey. 
      

Procedure: The entirety of the study takes places online through a Qualtrics survey. Participants will first answer a brief screening for our inclusion and exclusion criteria (age, gender, and psychological or neurological health issues). Eligible participants will then be consented. This is followed by the demographic questionnaire for age, ethnicity, income, and subjective health. Next, participants will complete the Future Time Perspective (FTP) survey, a 10-item scale to measure their subjective perception of how much time they feel they have left to live. This will be followed by the delay discounting practice round and task, in which participants choose which option they would prefer when presented with a smaller, sooner and a larger, later option.  Finally, they will be presented with the Savings and Safety Net subscale (from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau) to assess their saving habits and financial security across their lifetime . The total survey duration is estimated to be 7-8 minutes.
registration_responses.q16.question:
We are manipulating the time delay between the smaller, sooner option and the larger, later option. There are 4 levels of this variable: days, weeks, months, years. Each level has 3 sub-levels: a low-point, a midpoint, and a high-point. To enable investigations into framing effects, the high-point of one level is equivalent to the low-point of the subsequent level (i.e: 12 months and 1 year).

The delay discounting task itself is comprised of 36 task trials, and 3 catch trials which are used as attention checks. We use a combination of 12 time intervals and 3 hypothetical discount rates to create 36 delay discounting trials. We use the following time intervals: 1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 4 weeks, 1 month, 6 months, 12 months, 1 year, 5 year, and 10 years. We use the three different discount rates: k= .1, k= .05, and k=.005. In order to estimate an appropriate future amount, corresponding to the three discount rates and the given time delays, we used the following formula: reward=SV * (1+ k*days). In this formula, SV (subjective value) is the dollar amount of the reward today (set to $10 in every trial), reward is the dollar amount in the future after a given time delay, k is the discount rate, and days is the time delay (given in days). We operationalized a month to be 28 days.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The primary outcome variable is the acceptance rate, or the proportion of sooner options chosen in the delay discounting task. We will measure age (in years) as the continuous covariate, and will measure future time perspective, as measured by the FTP scale (Carstensen and Lang, 1996), as a mediator.

registration_responses.q19.question:
H1: We hypothesize that across all ages, we will see greater discounting (or greater proportion of sooner options) with longer time delays.

H2: We hypothesize that this increase in discounting for longer time delays will vary by age. Specifically, we predict that age differences in time preferences will only appear with longer time delays. For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.

We will test these hypotheses by predicting the proportion of sooner options chosen with two models:

First, we will test a 3 (k-values: 0.1, 0.05, 0.005) by 4 (time: days, weeks, months, years) by Age (25-84 years) ANCOVA. 

H1: Main effect of delay with longer delays (years) having greater acceptance of sooner option.
H2: Age * Delay interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (years)

Next, we will convert the categorical predictors above into continuous variables. The three k values will be log-transformed (-1, -1.301, -2.301) to reduce skewness and the twelve time delays will be converted into a common scale: number of days (1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 14 days, 28 days, 30 days, 180 days, 365 days, 1825 days, 1650 days). These two continuous predictors (log(k) and delay in days) will be used in a linear model.


H1: Main effect of number of days such that longer delays ( > 365 days) having greater acceptance of the sooner option.
H2: Age * number of days interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (>365 days)

One prominent theory of aging, socioemotional selectivity theory (SST), suggests that older adults become more present-oriented than younger adults because their future is more limited. Because of limited time horizons, older adults view the future as more uncertain, and this uncertainty may lead older adults to discount future rewards more than younger adults. Thus, for older adults, the greater the delay between now and an outcome, the greater their uncertainty about whether they will be alive and able to realize that outcome. This predicts that for longer time delays, older adults will discount more than younger adults. However, for shorter time delays older adults should not show a differences from younger adults. This hypothesis has not been empirically tested. Our goal is to clarify the effect that age has on delay discounting by systematically examining discounting when time delays of vary greatly in terms of magnitude.

For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.

question.value:
Participants: We will collect data from 276 participants (ages 25-84). The sample will be subdivided into six age categories, or bins (i.e: 25-34, 35-44, 45-54, 55-64. 65-74, 75-84). Each bin will have an equal number of participants (i.e: 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23). Finally, to build a sample that is representative of the US population, we will recruit participants to match the racial diversity described in the most recent US census (i.e: 75% Caucasian, 13% African-American, 5% Asian, etc).
Participants will be recruited with Qualtrics Panels, a service designed to recruit individuals from pre-existing participant pools, based on the criteria of researchers. Qualtrics Panels compensates the participant with Qualtrics points that can ultimately be redeemed for gift cards. We will include healthy participants between the ages of 25-84 and exclude participants with any psychological or neurological health issues as indicated by our online screening survey. 
      

Procedure: The entirety of the study takes places online through a Qualtrics survey. Participants will first answer a brief screening for our inclusion and exclusion criteria (age, gender, and psychological or neurological health issues). Eligible participants will then be consented. This is followed by the demographic questionnaire for age, ethnicity, income, and subjective health. Next, participants will complete the Future Time Perspective (FTP) survey, a 10-item scale to measure their subjective perception of how much time they feel they have left to live. This will be followed by the delay discounting practice round and task, in which participants choose which option they would prefer when presented with a smaller, sooner and a larger, later option.  Finally, they will be presented with the Savings and Safety Net subscale (from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau) to assess their saving habits and financial security across their lifetime . The total survey duration is estimated to be 7-8 minutes.

q13.value: As indicated by power analyses, we will have a sample size of 276 individuals between the ages of 25 and 85 years old. The sample will be subdivided into six age bins (i.e 25-34 35-44,...75-85) and within each age bin there will be an equal number of participants (i.e 46), and an equal number of men and women (i.e: 23).

q14.value: In order to detect a small effect size (Cohen's d= 0.2) with 80% power, power analyses indicated that we would need a sample size of 275. The sample was rounded to 276 to have an equal number of participants in each of the six bins.

q15.value: Qualtrics Panels will terminate participant recruitment and data collection when we have reached the target sample size, with the target composition of participants in each bin (i.e: equal numbers of men and women).

question.value:
We are manipulating the time delay between the smaller, sooner option and the larger, later option. There are 4 levels of this variable: days, weeks, months, years. Each level has 3 sub-levels: a low-point, a midpoint, and a high-point. To enable investigations into framing effects, the high-point of one level is equivalent to the low-point of the subsequent level (i.e: 12 months and 1 year).

The delay discounting task itself is comprised of 36 task trials, and 3 catch trials which are used as attention checks. We use a combination of 12 time intervals and 3 hypothetical discount rates to create 36 delay discounting trials. We use the following time intervals: 1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 4 weeks, 1 month, 6 months, 12 months, 1 year, 5 year, and 10 years. We use the three different discount rates: k= .1, k= .05, and k=.005. In order to estimate an appropriate future amount, corresponding to the three discount rates and the given time delays, we used the following formula: reward=SV * (1+ k*days). In this formula, SV (subjective value) is the dollar amount of the reward today (set to $10 in every trial), reward is the dollar amount in the future after a given time delay, k is the discount rate, and days is the time delay (given in days). We operationalized a month to be 28 days.

The primary outcome variable is the acceptance rate, or the proportion of sooner options chosen in the delay discounting task. We will measure age (in years) as the continuous covariate, and will measure future time perspective, as measured by the FTP scale (Carstensen and Lang, 1996), as a mediator.

H1: We hypothesize that across all ages, we will see greater discounting (or greater proportion of sooner options) with longer time delays.

H2: We hypothesize that this increase in discounting for longer time delays will vary by age. Specifically, we predict that age differences in time preferences will only appear with longer time delays. For shorter time delays (days, weeks, months), there will be no age differences in discount rates. For longer time delays (years), older adults will show greater discounting than younger adults because of uncertainty about their future.

We will test these hypotheses by predicting the proportion of sooner options chosen with two models:

First, we will test a 3 (k-values: 0.1, 0.05, 0.005) by 4 (time: days, weeks, months, years) by Age (25-84 years) ANCOVA. 

H1: Main effect of delay with longer delays (years) having greater acceptance of sooner option.
H2: Age * Delay interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (years)

Next, we will convert the categorical predictors above into continuous variables. The three k values will be log-transformed (-1, -1.301, -2.301) to reduce skewness and the twelve time delays will be converted into a common scale: number of days (1 day, 4 days, 7 days, 14 days, 28 days, 30 days, 180 days, 365 days, 1825 days, 1650 days). These two continuous predictors (log(k) and delay in days) will be used in a linear model.


H1: Main effect of number of days such that longer delays ( > 365 days) having greater acceptance of the sooner option.
H2: Age * number of days interaction such that age difference only appear for longer delays (>365 days)

q21.value:
We will use two-tailed tests with a p-value of .05 to make inferences. 

When necessary, we will use Bonferroni corrections for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: We will include three catch trials in the delay discounting task where there is an obvious correct answer (unlike the other trials in the delay discounting task). If a participant chooses incorrectly on one of these catch trials, their survey immediately ends and they are escorted out of the session. We will not use the data from participants who are excluded due to catch trials, as we want to ensure that everyone is attending to the task, especially when it is so short. We plan to include all of the rest of the data points from other participants in our analyses.

q23.value: We don't expect to have any missing data. As the survey is being conducted online in Qualtrics, each question has been built to require a response before the participant can move on to the next question.

q24.value:
First, plan to investigate framing effects. We will test frame (large number with small unit vs small number with large unit) and Age on discounting in the relevant subset of trials. 

Second, we are curious about the relationship between future time perspective and discounting. We will test if FTP mediates the relationship between age and discounting, and whether or not this relationship is moderated by time delay.

Finally, we plan to investigate whether discount rates correlate with lifetime saving habits, specifically with the amount of money in liquid savings. If this relationship is found to be significant, we will control for wealth in our analyses.

registration_responses.q1: The effect of delay length on time preferences across adulthood
registration_responses.q2: Shelby Denise Leverett, Kendra Leigh Seaman, Christopher Garza
registration_responses.q3: Many decisions involve considering trade-offs between a smaller sooner option and a larger later option. In these situations, people tend to devalue, or discount, the later option. This devaluation is known as temporal discounting. If the smaller, sooner option occurs now, this is known as delay discounting. If the smaller, sooner option occurs in the future, this is known as intertemporal discounting. The extent to which the later option is discounted varies largely between people, and research has shown mixed age effects. Some studies have found that with age, people discount more steeply, others have found that with age people discount less steeply, and others have not found any evidence that age has an effect on temporal discounting at all.  We posit that one of the reasons for these heterogeneous results is that existing studies have used a mixture of time delays, ranging from days to years. One prominent theory of aging, socioemotional selectivity theory (SST), suggests that older adults become more present-oriented than younger adults because their future is more limited. Because of limited time horizons, older adults view the future as more uncertain, and this uncertainty may lead older adults to discount future rewards more than younger adults. Thus, for older adults, the greater the delay between now and an outcome, the greater their uncertainty about whether they will be alive and able to realize that outcome. This predicts that for longer time delays, older adults will discount more than younger adults. However, for shorter time delays older adults should not show a differences from younger adults. This hypothesis has not been empirically tested. Our goal is to clarify the effect that age has on delay discounting by systematically examining discounting when time delays of vary greatly in terms of magnitude.
